text:
Q: Problem in SSIS package in DATA FLOW TASK section A: 
DECLARE @Paramanter INT 
SET @Paramanter = ?

SELECT
    PatientReceptionHeaderPK,
    PatientPK,
    DoctorPK,
    InsuranceTypeCode,
    ReceptionDate_Shamsi
    FROM PatientReceptionHeader
    WHERE ReceptionDate_Shamsi >= FORMAT(DATEADD(DAY, @Paramanter,GETDATE()), 'yyyy/MM/dd', 'fa-IR')

    -- OR IF this still gives you an error, cast it to the CHAR(10) data type

    WHERE ReceptionDate_Shamsi >= FORMAT(DATEADD(DAY, CAST(@Paramanter AS CHAR(10)),GETDATE()), 'yyyy/MM/dd', 'fa-IR')

Q: Next.js 16 crashes on Windows 11 when opening localhost:3000 A:

The issue was caused by Turbopack, which is the default bundler in Next.js 16. On Windows 11, I think Turbopack can fail during file-system operations (especially renaming temporary manifest files), which makes bot next dev and next build exit with no errors. Think this is an issue related to Windows file locking.

I fixed the problem by switching back to Webpack, which avoids these issues entirely.

Updated scripts in package.json

"scripts": { "dev": "next dev --webpack", "build": "next build --webpack", "start": "next start" }

After adding the --webpack flag, both development and production builds work normally again.

Q: Minimizing and simplifying a 2D triangle mesh A:

What you are after is the (Boolean) union of a group of polygons, see this Wikipedia page, without holes (which requires extra computation as @yvesdaoust mentions), whilst preserving the inner edges that have not been broken in the process.

I think that is a customised operation that has no name at the moment. The links on the Wikipedia page are very old but may be a good start for a search - it looks like the clipper2 library can do the union part of what you want? Restoring the still-triangle-edges may take some extra coding.

Q: I want to improve my program thats about a React Tasklist A:

Can you try to get the code formatting to work? It's hard to read the second part.

Q: Child widgets not shown correctly if parent Frame is gridded later A:

The problem lies in the variable w. When the frame is gridded in __init__(), w=382, but when it is gridded later, w=1.

The solution is to create the window inside the canvas after the frame has been gridded.

Both in PeopleViewer.__init__() and VehicleViewer.__init__(), comment these 3 lines:

        self.canvas_in_frame_elements = tk.Canvas(self.frame_elements, borderwidth=0)
        self.frame_inside_canvas = ttk.Frame(self.canvas_in_frame_elements)
        self.frame_inside_canvas.columnconfigure((0, 2), weight=0, minsize=20)
        self.frame_inside_canvas.columnconfigure((1, 3), weight=1, uniform='elements')
        self.vsb = ttk.Scrollbar(self.frame_elements, orient="vertical", command=self.canvas_in_frame_elements.yview)
        self.canvas_in_frame_elements.configure(yscrollcommand=self.vsb.set)
        self.vsb.pack(side="right", fill="y")
        self.canvas_in_frame_elements.pack(side="left", fill="both", expand=True)
        # self.canvas_in_frame_elements.update()
        # w = self.canvas_in_frame_elements.winfo_width()
        # self.canvas_in_frame_elements.create_window((0, 0), window=self.frame_inside_canvas, anchor="nw", width=w)
        self.frame_inside_canvas.bind("<Configure>", self.onFrameConfigure)

Then, in PeopleViewer.update(), substitute

        if not self.frame.winfo_ismapped():
            self.frame.grid(row=0, column=0, sticky='nswe')
            print('PeopleViewer gridded')

with

        if not self.frame.winfo_ismapped():
            self.frame.grid(row=0, column=0, sticky='nswe')
            print('PeopleViewer gridded')

            self.canvas_in_frame_elements.update()
            w = self.canvas_in_frame_elements.winfo_width()
            self.canvas_in_frame_elements.create_window((0, 0), window=self.frame_inside_canvas, anchor="nw", width=w)

Which is the same as moving the 3 lines from __init__() to update().

And the same for and VehicleViewer.update().

Thanks @acw1668 for the heads up.

Q: Python subprocess failed with "is not recognized as an internal or external command" A:

I created a test application named hello.exe and placed it in C:\cygwin64\home\charl\cygwin64

This test app just prints "Hello World" to the console.

I think that your problem is the way you specified the new PATH in the export line. You need to use windows format.

Change export PATH=$PATH:/home/joe/ltx/bin to export PATH="$PATH:C:\cygwin64\home\joe\ltx\bin"

Opening the cygwin64 terminal I got the following results.

charl@R16 ~
$ export PATH="$PATH:C:\cygwin64\home\charl\cygwin64"
charl@R16 ~
$ hello
Hello World
charl@R16 ~
$ python
Python 3.12.7 | packaged by Anaconda, Inc. | (main, Oct  4 2024, 13:17:27) [MSC v.1929 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import subprocess
>>> subprocess.run(["hello", "-h"])
Hello World
CompletedProcess(args=['hello', '-h'], returncode=0)

Note: The above example does not apply to the original poster's question because ltx is a perl script. See comments below
